### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 83 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: An organism is considered to have an infection when a disease-causing agent, called a pathogen, establishes a viable presence in the organism. This can occur only if the pathogenic agent is able to reproduce itself in the host organism. The only agents believed until recently to be responsible for infections—viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites—reproduce and regulate their other life processes by means of genetic material, composed of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA). It was thus widely assumed that all pathogens contain such genetic material in their cellular structure. This assumption has been challenged, however, by scientists seeking to identify the pathogen that causes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a degenerative form of dementia in humans. CJD causes the brain to become riddled with tiny holes, like a sponge (evidence of extensive nerve cell death). Its symptoms include impaired muscle control, loss of mental acuity, memory loss, and chronic insomnia. Extensive experiments aimed at identifying the pathogen responsible for CJD have led surprisingly to the isolation of a disease agent lacking nucleic acid and consisting mainly, if not exclusively, of protein. Researchers coined the term "prion" for this new type of protein pathogen. Upon further study, scientists discovered that prions normally exist as harmless cellular proteins in many of the body's tissues, including white blood cells and nerve cells in the brain; however, they possess the capability of converting their structures into a dangerous abnormal shape. Prions exhibiting this abnormal conformation were found to have infectious properties and the ability to reproduce themselves in an unexpected way, by initiating a chain reaction that induces normally shaped prions to transform themselves on contact, one after another, into the abnormal, pathogenic conformation. This cascade of transformations produces a plaque, consisting of thread-like structures, that collects in the brain and ultimately destroys nerve cells. Because prions, unlike other pathogens, occur naturally in the body as proteins, the body does not produce an immune response when they are present. And in the absence of any effective therapy for preventing the cascade process by which affected prions reproduce themselves, CJD is inevitably fatal, though there are wide variations in pre-symptomatic incubation times and in how aggressively the disease progresses. Although the discovery of the link between prions and CJD was initially received with great skepticism in the scientific community, subsequent research has supported the conclusion that prions are an entirely new class of infectious pathogens. Furthermore, it is now believed that a similar process of protein malformation may be involved in other, more common degenerative neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. This possibility has yet to be fully explored, however, and the exact mechanisms by which prions reproduce themselves and cause cellular destruction have yet to be completely understood.
Question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?
Choices:
  A: Although most organisms are known to produce several kinds of proteins, the mechanism by which isolated protein molecules such as prions reproduce themselves is not yet known in detail.
  B: Research into the cause of CJD has uncovered a deadly class of protein pathogens uniquely capable of reproducing themselves without genetic material.
  C: Recent research suggests that prions may be responsible not only for CJD, but for most other degenerative neurological conditions as well.
  D: The assertion that prions cause CJD has been received with great skepticism in the scientific community because it undermines a firmly entrenched view about the nature of pathogens.
  E: Even though prions contain no genetic material, it has become clear that they are somehow capable of reproducing themselves.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses the discovery of prions as a new type of protein pathogen that lacks nucleic acid but is capable of reproducing itself and causing disease.
  Prions exist naturally in the body as proteins, and some prions can convert themselves into a pathogenic, abnormal form capable of inducing other prions to transform.
Thought:
  The passage discusses the discovery of prions and how they reproduce to cause CJD and other related diseases.
  The passage mainly focuses on the discovery of prions as new type of pathogen, their properties, and their link to CJD and other degenerative neurological conditions. 
  Therefore, the answer is B: research into the cause of CJD has uncovered a deadly class of protein pathogens uniquely capable of reproducing themselves without genetic material.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("B")

  Prions are unique in that they lack genetic material and are capable of reproducing themselves without it, by inducing normally shaped prions to transform themselves into the abnormal pathogenic conformation.

  This is an important discovery since it undermines the previously held view that all infections are caused by agents with cellular structures containing genetic material. 
  Therefore, the main point of the passage is that research into CJD uncovered a new type of infectious protein pathogen known as prions that can reproduce and cause significant brain damage.

Response 6:
Knowledge: 
The passage describes the discovery of a new class of infectious pathogens called prions that lack nucleic acid and reproduce themselves by converting other proteins to abnormal, pathogenic conformation leading to the destruction of nerve cells. The new pathogen was discovered as researchers sought to identify the pathogen that causes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a degenerative form of dementia in humans. Prions usually exist as harmless cellular proteins in many of the body's tissues, including nerve cells in the brain. Prions, unlike other pathogens, occur naturally in the body as proteins, thereby, the body does not produce an immune response when they are present. The exact mechanisms by which prions reproduce themselves and cause cellular destruction have yet to be completely understood and it is now believed that a similar process of protein malformation may be involved in other, more common degenerative neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease.
Thought: 
  The passage primarily discusses a newly discovered agent called prion, which lacks nucleic acid and is responsible for causing CJD while being capable of converting normal proteins to abnormal, pathogenic conformation leading to the destruction of nerve cells. Further research has revealed that these prions exist naturally as cellular proteins and can be harmful only when they undergo a change in shape and structure. Their unique ability to replicate themselves without genetic material is a major discovery and differentiates them from other pathogens. Hence, option B seems to be the most accurate choice.
Criticism: 
  There is no mention of other organisms in the passage besides a reference to viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites that were previously assumed to be responsible for causing infections. Option A talks about proteins in general instead of prions, as described in the passage. Option C's argument that prions may be responsible not only for CJD, but for most other degenerative neurological conditions as well is not completely described in the passage. Option D's suggestion that the discovery of prions received great skepticism in the scientific community because it undermined a firmly entrenched view about the nature of pathogens seems to contradict the statement that "subsequent research has supported the conclusion that prions are an entirely new class of infectious pathogens." Option E seems to accurately describe the passage, but it is not as specific as option B.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 7:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses the discovery of prions as a new type of protein pathogen responsible for CJD.
  Prions lack nucleic acid and reproduce themselves by initiating a chain reaction that changes the structures of other proteins.
  This protein conversion process produces a plaque that destroys nerve cells, leading to CJD.
  The body does not produce an immune response to prions, and there is no effective therapy for CJD.

  The passage provides information on the structure and mechanism of reproduction of prions as different from other traditional pathogens such as viruses and bacteria.
  The passage mentions that prions exist naturally in the body as proteins and can reproduce themselves by initiating a chain reaction.
  Therefore, the main point of the passage is that research into the cause of CJD has uncovered a deadly class of protein pathogens uniquely capable of reproducing themselves without genetic material.

  Researchers call this new type of protein pathogen "prion." Prions induce normally shaped prions to transform themselves into abnormal, pathogenic conformation producing a plaque that collects in the brain and ultimately destroys nerve cells.

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 84 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: There are some basic conceptual problems hovering about the widespread use of brain scans as pictures of mental activity. As applied to medical diagnosis (for example, in diagnosing a brain tumor), a brain scan is similar in principle to an X-ray: it is a way of seeing inside the body. Its value is straightforward and indubitable. However, the use of neuroimaging in psychology is a fundamentally different kind of enterprise. It is a research method the validity of which depends on a premise: that the mind can be analyzed into separate and distinct modules, or components, and further that these modules are instantiated in localized brain regions. This premise is known as the modular theory of mind. It may in fact be that neither mental activity, nor the physical processes that constitute it, are decomposable into independent modules. Psychologist William Uttal contends that rather than distinct entities, the various mental processes are likely to be properties of a more general mental activity that is distributed throughout the brain. It cannot be said, for instance, that the amygdala is the seat of emotion and the prefrontal cortex is the seat of reason, as the popular press sometimes claims. For when I get angry, I generally do so for a reason. To cleanly separate emotion from reason-giving makes a hash of human experience. But if this critique of the modular theory of mind is valid, how can one account for the fact that brain scans do, in fact, reveal well-defined areas that "light up," in response to various cognitive tasks? In the case of functional magnetic resonance imaging (FMRI), what you are seeing when you look at a brain scan is actually the result of a subtraction. The FMRI is usually interpreted as a map of the rate of oxygen use in different parts of the brain, which stands as a measure of metabolic activity. But what it actually depicts is the differential rate of oxygen use: one first takes a baseline measurement in the control condition, then a second measurement while the subject is performing some cognitive task. The baseline measurement is then subtracted from the on-task measurement. The reasoning, seemingly plausible, is that whatever remains after the subtraction represents the metabolic activity associated solely with the cognitive task in question. One immediately obvious (but usually unremarked) problem is that this method obscures the fact that the entire brain is active in both conditions. A false impression of neat functional localization is given by differential brain scans that subtract out all the distributed brain functions. This subtractive method produces striking images of the brain at work. But isn't the modular theory of mind ultimately attractive in part because it is illustrated so well by the products of the subtractive method?
Question: According to the passage, psychologist William Uttal contends that the various mental processes are likely to be
Choices:
  A: independent modules that are based in different areas of the brain
  B: essentially an amalgamation of emotion and reason
  C: generally uniform in their rates of oxygen use
  D: detectable using brain scans enhanced by means of the subtractive method
  E: features of a general mental activity that is spread throughout the brain
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The passage discusses the modular theory of mind and the use of brain scans to study mental activity.
  William Uttal critiques the modular theory of mind and proposes an alternative view.
  A: This statement is a description of the modular theory of mind, not William Uttal's critique.
  B: This statement describes Uttal's critique of the modular theory of mind.
  C: This statement does not accurately reflect Uttal's critique or the passage's discussion.
  D: This statement describes the subtractive method used in brain scans, but it does not relate to Uttal's critique.
  E: This statement describes Uttal's alternative view that the various mental processes are features of a general mental activity that is spread throughout the brain.
Thought:
  The question asks for Uttal's view of mental processes.
  The passage states that Uttal criticizes the modular theory of mind and suggests that mental processes are not independent modules based in different areas of the brain.
  Uttal argues that mental processes are features of a more general mental activity that is distributed throughout the brain.
  This matches answer choice E.
Action: Answer("E")

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 85 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Passage ATo a neuroscientist, you are your brain; nothing causes your behavior other than the operations of your brain. This viewpoint, together with recent findings in neuroscience, radically changes the way we think about the law. The official line in the law is that all that matters is whether you are rational, but you can have someone who is totally rational even though their strings are being pulled by something beyond their control. Indeed, people who believe themselves to be making a free and rational moral choice may really be deluding themselves—a brain scan might show that such a choice correlates with activity in emotional centers in the brain rather than in the region of the brain associated with deliberative problem solving. This insight suggests that the criminal-justice system should abandon the idea of retribution—the idea that bad people should be punished because of their freely chosen immoral acts—which is now dominant as a justification of punishment. Instead, the law should focus on deterring future harms. In some cases, this might mean lighter punishments. If it is really true that we do not get any prevention bang from our punishment buck when we punish some person, then it is not worth punishing that person. Passage B Neuroscience constantly produces new mechanistic descriptions of how the physical brain causes behavior, adding fuel to the deterministic view that all human action is causally necessitated by events that are independent of the will. It has long been argued, however, that the concept of free will can coexist with determinism.In 1954 English philosopher Alfred J. Ayer put forth a theory of "soft determinism." He argued, as the philosopher David Hume had two centuries earlier, that even in a deterministic world, a person can still act freely. Ayer distinguished between free actions and constrained actions. Free actions are those that are caused by internal sources, by one's own will (unless one is suffering from a disorder). Constrained actions are those that are caused by external sources, for example, by someone or something forcing you physically or mentally to perform an action, as in hypnosis or in mental disorders such as kleptomania. When someone performs a free action to do A, he or she could have done B instead, since no external source precluded doing so. When someone performs a constrained action to do A, he or she could have done only A.Ayer argued that actions are free as long as they are not constrained. It is not the existence of a cause but the source of the cause that determines whether an action is free. Although Ayer did not explicitly discuss the brain's role, one could make the analogy that those actions—and indeed those wills-that originate from a disease-free brain are not constrained, and are therefore free, even though they may be determined.
Question: Which one of the following concepts plays a role in the argument of passage B but not in that of passage A?
Choices:
  A: mental disorder
  B: free choice
  C: causality
  D: self-delusion
  E: moral responsibility
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Passage A argues that neuroscience suggests the criminal-justice system should abandon the idea of retribution and focus on deterring future harms.
  Passage A suggests that people who believe themselves to be making a free and rational moral choice may really be deluding themselves.
  Passage A argues that you are your brain, and nothing causes your behavior other than the operations of your brain.
  Passage B argues that, even in a deterministic world, a person can still act freely, according to Alfred J. Ayer's theory of "soft determinism."
  Passage B distinguishes between free actions and constrained actions.
  Passage B argues that actions are free as long as they are not constrained.
Thought: 
  Passage A argues that all behavior is caused by the brain, and people who believe they act freely may be deluding themselves.
  Therefore, the concept of free choice is discussed in passage A.
  Passage B, on the other hand, argues that free choice can coexist with determinism.
  Passage B distinguishes between free actions and constrained actions, and argues that actions are free as long as they are not constrained.
  Therefore, the concept of constrained actions is discussed in passage B.
  Mental disorders are not specifically discussed in either passage.
  Causality is discussed in both passages.
  Self-delusion is discussed in passage A, but not in passage B.
  Moral responsibility is discussed only in passage A.
  Therefore, the answer is B: free choice is discussed in passage B but not in passage A.
Criticism: 
  Your thought process is correct.
Action: Answer("B")

  Passage B argues that free will can coexist with determinism, and actions are free as long as they are not constrained.

  Mental disorder, causality, and self-delusion are also discussed in the passages, but they do not play a role in the argument that distinguishes free and constrained actions.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 9:
Knowledge:
  Passage A argues that behaviors are caused by the brain and not by free choice and that this should alter the way we think about the law.
  Passage A suggests that the law should focus on deterring future harms instead of retribution.
  Passage B argues that free actions can coexist with determinism but that constrained actions cannot.
  Passage B argues that actions are free as long as they are not constrained.
Thought:
  Passage A argues against the idea of free choice in behavior, suggesting that the brain wholly causes behavior.
  Passage B argues that actions can be free as long as they are not constrained even within a deterministic view.
  Mental disorder could play a role in either argument as it could fall under what constrains actions or what causes the brain to act in a certain way.
  Free choice is mentioned in Passage B as a viable concept to explain "free actions."
  Causality is mentioned in both passages as a way to understand how behavior is caused.
  Self-delusion is mentioned in Passage A and is used to suggest people may not be making free and rational moral choices.
  Moral responsibility is mentioned in Passage A as a reason given for punishment, but this view is challenged.
  Therefore, the answer is B: free choice.

  None.

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 86 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Advances in scientific understanding often do not build directly or smoothly in response to the data that are amassed, and in retrospect, after a major revision of theory, it may seem strange that a crucial bypothesis was long overlooked. A case in point is the discovery of a means by which the nuclei of atoms can be split Between 1934, when a group ofitalian physicists including Enrico Fermi first bombarded uranium with neutrons, and 1939, when exiled Austrian physicist Lise Meitner provided the crucial theoretical connection, scientists compiled increasing evidence that nuclear fission had been achieved, without, however, recognizing what they were witnessing.Earlier, even before the neutron and proton composition of atomic nuclei had been experimentally demonstrated, sometheoretical physicists had produced calculations indicating that in principle it should be possible to break atoms apart. But the neutron-bombardment experiments were not aimed at achieving such a result, and researchers were not even receptive to the possibility that it might happen in that context. A common view was that a neutron's breaking apart a uranium nucleus would be analogous to a pebble, thrown through a window, causing a house to collapse.In Berlin, Meitner pursued research related to that of the Italians, discovering a puzzling group of radioactive substances produced by neutron bombardment of uranium. Fermi and others achieved numerous similar results. These products remained unidentified partly because precise chemical analyses were hampered by the minute quantities of the substances produced and the dangers of working with highly radioactive materials, but more significantly because of the expectation that they would all be elements close to uranium in nuclear composition. In 1938 Meitner escaped from Nazi Germany and undertook related research in Sweden, but her research partner Otto Hahn kept her informed of his continuing experimentation. Late in that year he wrote to her of a surprising result: one of the substances resulting from the neutron bombardment of uranium had been conclusively identified as barium, an element whose structure would have made it impossible to produce through any mechanism he envisaged as being involved in the experiments. Hahn even remarked that, despite the clear chemical evidence of what had occmred, it went "against all previous experiences of nuclear physics," but be also noted that together the number of protons and neutrons in the nuclei of barium and technetium, the accompanying product of the experiment, added up to the number of such particles that compose a uranium nucleus.It was Meitner who finally recognized the significance of the data in relation to underlying theoretical considerations: the researchers had actually been splitting uranium atoms. Coining the term "nuclear fission," she quickly submitted her conclusion for publication in a paper coauthored with pbysicist Otto Frisch. When scientists in Europe and North America rushed to corroborate the findings, it became clear that the relevant evidence had been present for some rime, lacking mainly the right conceptual link.
Question: According to the passage, which one of the following was true of the physics community during the 1930s?
Choices:
  A: It neglected earlier theoretical developments.
  B: It reevaluated caleulations indicating that atoms could be split
  C: It never identified the by-products ofneutron bombardment ofuraniwn.
  D: It showed that uraniwn atoms were the easiest to split.
  E: It recogoized the daogers of working with radioactive substances.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Scientists discovered nuclear fission in the 1930s.
  Before the discovery, some theoretical physicists had produced calculations indicating that it should be possible to break atoms apart.
  In 1934, a group of Italian physicists, including Enrico Fermi, first bombarded uranium with neutrons.
  In 1939, exiled Austrian physicist Lise Meitner provided the crucial theoretical connection to recognize the significance of the data in relation to underlying theoretical considerations.
Thought: 
  The physics community in the 1930s compiled increasing evidence that nuclear fission had been achieved without recognizing what they were witnessing.
  Earlier, some theoretical physicists had produced calculations indicating the possibility to break atoms apart.
  The neutron-bombardment experiments were not aimed at achieving such a result, and researchers were not even receptive to the possibility that it might happen in that context.
  This indicates that the community neglected earlier theoretical developments.
  It also indicates that the community did not reevaluate old calculations.
  The passage does not mention that the community never identified the by-products of neutron bombardment of uranium or that uranium atoms were the easiest to split.
  It also mentions that precise chemical analyses were hampered by the minute quantities of the substances produced and the dangers of working with highly radioactive materials.
  This indicates that the community recognized the dangers of working with radioactive substances.
  Therefore, the answer is A: It neglected earlier theoretical developments.
Criticism: 
  There is no direct evidence to support the statement that the physics community in the 1930s neglected earlier theoretical developments. The passage only mentions that some theoretical physicists had produced calculations indicating the possibility to break atoms apart.
  However, the passage also mentions that the neutron-bombardment experiments were not aimed at achieving such a result and that researchers were not even receptive to the possibility that it might happen in that context, indicating that the community did not recognize the significance of earlier theoretical developments.
Action: Answer("A")

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 87 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Advances in scientific understanding often do not build directly or smoothly in response to the data that are amassed, and in retrospect, after a major revision of theory, it may seem strange that a crucial bypothesis was long overlooked. A case in point is the discovery of a means by which the nuclei of atoms can be split Between 1934, when a group ofitalian physicists including Enrico Fermi first bombarded uranium with neutrons, and 1939, when exiled Austrian physicist Lise Meitner provided the crucial theoretical connection, scientists compiled increasing evidence that nuclear fission had been achieved, without, however, recognizing what they were witnessing.Earlier, even before the neutron and proton composition of atomic nuclei had been experimentally demonstrated, sometheoretical physicists had produced calculations indicating that in principle it should be possible to break atoms apart. But the neutron-bombardment experiments were not aimed at achieving such a result, and researchers were not even receptive to the possibility that it might happen in that context. A common view was that a neutron's breaking apart a uranium nucleus would be analogous to a pebble, thrown through a window, causing a house to collapse.In Berlin, Meitner pursued research related to that of the Italians, discovering a puzzling group of radioactive substances produced by neutron bombardment of uranium. Fermi and others achieved numerous similar results. These products remained unidentified partly because precise chemical analyses were hampered by the minute quantities of the substances produced and the dangers of working with highly radioactive materials, but more significantly because of the expectation that they would all be elements close to uranium in nuclear composition. In 1938 Meitner escaped from Nazi Germany and undertook related research in Sweden, but her research partner Otto Hahn kept her informed of his continuing experimentation. Late in that year he wrote to her of a surprising result: one of the substances resulting from the neutron bombardment of uranium had been conclusively identified as barium, an element whose structure would have made it impossible to produce through any mechanism he envisaged as being involved in the experiments. Hahn even remarked that, despite the clear chemical evidence of what had occmred, it went "against all previous experiences of nuclear physics," but be also noted that together the number of protons and neutrons in the nuclei of barium and technetium, the accompanying product of the experiment, added up to the number of such particles that compose a uranium nucleus.It was Meitner who finally recognized the significance of the data in relation to underlying theoretical considerations: the researchers had actually been splitting uranium atoms. Coining the term "nuclear fission," she quickly submitted her conclusion for publication in a paper coauthored with pbysicist Otto Frisch. When scientists in Europe and North America rushed to corroborate the findings, it became clear that the relevant evidence had been present for some rime, lacking mainly the right conceptual link.
Question: Which one of the following is most nearly equivalent to what the author means by "the relevant evidence" (line 62)?
Choices:
  A: the results of experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by the physics community between 1934 and 1939
  B: the results of related experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by Meitner in 1938
  C: the clear chemical evidence that Hahn had found of barium's being produced by neutron bombardment of uranium
  D: the fact that the sum of the number of protons and neutrons in the nuclei of barium and technetium was the same as the number of these particles in a uranium nucleus
  E: the fact that radioactive products of neutron bombardment of uranium went unidentified for so long
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses the history of the discovery of nuclear fission.
  The physicists had compiled increasing evidence that nuclear fission had been achieved.
  Italian physicists including Enrico Fermi first bombarded uranium with neutrons.
  In 1938, Lise Meitner discovered that one of the substances resulting from the neutron bombardment of uranium had been conclusively identified as barium, an element whose structure would have made it impossible to produce through any mechanism he envisaged as being involved in the experiments.
Thought: 
  According to the passage, the relevant evidence had been present for some time, lacking mainly the right conceptual link. 
  In this sense, "the relevant evidence" is the evidence that the researchers had actually been splitting uranium atoms
  Therefore, the author means by "the relevant evidence" (line 62) as the "results of experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by the physics community between 1934 and 1939".
  The evidence is not the results of related experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by Meitner in 1938 nor the clear chemical evidence that Hahn had found of barium's being produced by neutron bombardment of uranium.
  Nor is the evidence the fact that the sum of the number of protons and neutrons in the nuclei of barium and technetium was the same as the number of these particles in a uranium nucleus because this fact helps the physicists draw an accurate conclusion.
  The fact that radioactive products of neutron bombardment of uranium went unidentified for so long is irrelevant to the definition of the term "the relevant evidence" (line 62).
  Therefore, the answer is A: the results of experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by the physics community between 1934 and 1939.
Criticism: 
  You are correct. The relevant evidence refers to the results of experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by the physics community between 1934 and 1939.

One of the results of neutron bombardment of uranium was the production of a puzzling group of radioactive substances, which remained unidentified for some time.   The author discusses the scientists' discovery of nuclear fission in the period between 1934 and 1939.
  Lise Meitner provided the crucial theoretical connection for the experimental findings of other physicists.
  Researchers compiled increasing evidence that nuclear fission had been achieved, without recognizing what they were witnessing.
  Otto Hahn wrote to Meitner in 1938 about a surprising result: one of the substances resulting from the neutron bombardment of uranium had been identified as barium.
Thought:
  The question asks for the meaning of the relevant evidence referred to in the passage. 
  The relevant evidence refers to what the researchers were actually witnessing in their experiments, which was the breaking apart of uranium atoms through nuclear fission.
  The evidence was present for some time before Lise Meitner recognized its significance based on theoretical considerations. 
  Therefore, the relevant evidence is not (B) the results of experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by Meitner in 1938, but (A) the results of experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by the physics community between 1934 and 1939. 
  Option (C), the clear chemical evidence that Hahn found of barium's being produced by neutron bombardment of uranium, is part of the relevant evidence, but not equivalent to the overall evidence. 
  Option (D), the fact that the sum of the number of protons and neutrons in the nuclei of barium and technetium was the same as the number of these particles in a uranium nucleus, is also part of the evidence, but not its entirety or equivalent to it. Therefore, (A) is the best answer.
Criticism:
  There is no flaw in the facts, logic, or reasoning used to arrive at the answer (A) in this case.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 8:
Knowledge:
  The scientific community was conducting neutron bombardment experiments on uranium.
  The goal of these experiments was not to achieve nuclear fission.
  Meitner discovered a group of radioactive substances produced by neutron bombardment of uranium.
  Hahn found out that barium had been produced as one of the products of the neutron bombardment of uranium.
  Meitner recognized the significance of the data and concluded that uranium atoms had been split.
Thought:
  The relevant evidence refers to the data that gave proof that uranium atoms were split.
  Since uranium atoms were split and nuclear fission had been achieved, it can be inferred that the evidence that the author is referring to is:
  When Meitner discovered the group of radioactive substances produced by neutron bombardment of uranium, and when Hahn found out that barium had been produced as one of the products of the neutron bombardment of uranium.
Therefore, Answer("C") the clear chemical evidence that Hahn had found of barium's being produced by neutron bombardment of uranium is the most nearly equivalent to what the author means by "the relevant evidence".
Response 9:
Knowledge: 
  The author discusses the discovery of nuclear fission and how it was achieved.
  Before the discovery, scientists were compiling increasing evidence that nuclear fission had been achieved, but without recognizing it.
  In 1938, Otto Hahn discovered a radioactive substance resulting from the neutron bombardment of uranium that was conclusively identified as barium, an element that should have been impossible to produce through any mechanism he envisaged being involved in the experiments.
  It was Meitner who finally recognized that the researchers had actually been splitting uranium atoms.
Thought:
  The relevant evidence must refer to evidence that was present and could have led to the discovery of nuclear fission had scientists made the right conceptual link.
  The results of experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by the physics community between 1934 and 1939 and the related experiments in neutron bombardment of uranium conducted by Meitner in 1938 may have been the initial steps towards the discovery of nuclear fission, but they were not the relevant evidence that led to the discovery.
  The clear chemical evidence that Hahn had found of barium's being produced by neutron bombardment of uranium was a crucial piece of the puzzle since it was the first conclusive evidence that a uranium atom had been split. Therefore, it is a strong candidate for the relevant evidence.
  The fact that the sum of the number of protons and neutrons in the nuclei of barium and technetium was the same as the number of these particles in a uranium nucleus was significant but not on its own relevant evidence.
  The fact that radioactive products of neutron bombardment of uranium went unidentified for so long was not the relevant evidence that led to the discovery of nuclear fission.
  Therefore, the best answer is C: the clear chemical evidence that Hahn had found of barium's being produced by neutron bombardment of uranium.
Criticism: 
  Your analysis is correct.

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 88 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: The painter Roy Lichtenstein helped to define pop art—the movement that incorporated commonplace objects and commercial-art techniques into paintings— by paraphrasing the style of comic books in his work. His merger of a popular genre with the forms and intentions of fine art generated a complex result: while poking fun at the pretensions of the art world, Lichtenstein's work also managed to convey a seriousness of theme that enabled it to transcend mere parody. That Lichtenstein's images were fine art was at first difficult to see, because, with their word balloons and highly stylized figures, they looked like nothing more than the comic book panels from which they were copied. Standard art history holds that pop art emerged as an impersonal alternative to the histrionics of abstract expressionism, a movement in which painters conveyed their private attitudes and emotions using nonrepresentational techniques. The truth is that by the time pop art first appeared in the early 1960s, abstract expressionism had already lost much of its force. Pop art painters weren't quarreling with the powerful early abstract expressionist work of the late 1940s but with a second generation of abstract expressionists whose work seemed airy, high-minded, and overly lyrical. Pop art paintings were full of simple black lines and large areas of primary color. Lichtenstein's work was part of a general rebellion against the fading emotional power of abstract expressionism, rather than an aloof attempt to ignore it. But if rebellion against previous art by means of the careful imitation of a popular genre were all that characterized Lichtenstein's work, it would possess only the reflective power that parodies have in relation to their subjects. Beneath its cartoonish methods, his work displayed an impulse toward realism, an urge to say that what was missing from contemporary painting was the depiction of contemporary life. The stilted romances and war stories portrayed in the comic books on which he based his canvases, the stylized automobiles, hot dogs, and table lamps that appeared in his pictures, were reflections of the culture Lichtenstein inhabited. But, in contrast to some pop art, Lichtenstein's work exuded not a jaded cynicism about consumer culture, but a kind of deliberate naivete, intended as a response to the excess of sophistication he observed not only in the later abstract expressionists but in some other pop artists. With the comics— typically the domain of youth and innocence—as his reference point, a nostalgia fills his paintings that gives them, for all their surface bravado, an inner sweetness. His persistent use of comic-art conventions demonstrates a faith in reconciliation, not only between cartoons and fine art, but between parody and true feeling.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, would most challenge the author's characterization of Lichtenstein?
Choices:
  A: Lichtenstein frequently attended exhibitions by abstract expressionist painters in the 1960s.
  B: Lichtenstein praised a contemporary abstract expressionist in the 1960s for producing an atypically emotional painting.
  C: Lichtenstein praised an early abstract expressionist for producing emotional paintings.
  D: Lichtenstein criticized a pop artist in the 1960s for producing emotional paintings.
  E: Lichtenstein criticized a pop artist in the 1960s for producing paintings void of emotion.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The passage describes Roy Lichtenstein as a pop artist who incorporated comic book style into fine art.
  Lichtenstein's work was a rebellion against the fading emotional power of abstract expressionism.
  His work was a reflection of contemporary life, displaying an impulse toward realism.
  Lichtenstein's work exuded a kind of deliberate naivete, intended as a response to the excess of sophistication he observed.
Thought:
  The author characterizes Lichtenstein as someone who incorporated comic book style into fine art and as a reflection of contemporary life exhibiting a deliberate naivete.
  If Lichtenstein frequently attended exhibitions by abstract expressionist painters in the 1960s, it would not necessarily challenge the author's characterization of Lichtenstein.
  If Lichtenstein praised a contemporary abstract expressionist in the 1960s or an early abstract expressionist for producing emotional paintings, it's not clear that it would necessarily challenge the author's characterization of Lichtenstein.
  If Lichtenstein criticized a pop artist in the 1960s for producing emotional paintings or paintings void of emotion, it's not clear how it would challenge the author's characterization of Lichtenstein.
  Nothing in the answer choices directly challenges the author's characterization of Lichtenstein.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")
Response 1:

  The passage discusses the context and characteristics of Lichtenstein's pop art, his use of comic-art conventions, and his exploration of the depiction of contemporary life.
Thought:
  The author portrays Lichtenstein's pop art as a deliberate and complex expression of realism that combines comic-art conventions with a nostalgia that conveys a sweetness and a faith in reconciliation. The author also suggests that Lichtenstein did not aim to ignore or rebel against abstract expressionism, but to respond to its fading emotional power. Therefore, something that contradicts or undermines these characterizations would challenge the author's description of Lichtenstein.
  A: Lichtenstein attending exhibitions by abstract expressionist painters does not necessarily contradict the author's view of his work, since it is consistent with Lichtenstein's background and interest in art history. Also, it does not necessarily imply that he rejected or dismissed abstract expressionism in the way the author describes. Therefore, this is not the answer.

Therefore, this is not the answer.

Therefore, this is not the answer.
  E: Lichtenstein criticizing a pop artist for producing paintings void of emotion is not necessarily inconsistent with the author's view of Lichtenstein. It could suggest that Lichtenstein valued emotional expression in art but questioned whether some pop artists achieved it effectively. Therefore, this is not the answer.

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 89 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Before contact with Europeans, the Haudenosaune, a group of nations in northeastern North America also known as the Iroquois, had been developing a form of communication, primarily for political purposes, that used wampum, a bead carved from seashell. Most historians have insisted that wampum was primarily a form of money. While wampum certainly did become a medium of exchange among Europeans and Haudenosaune alike, this was due to the Europeans, who misinterpreted the significance of wampum and used it solely to purchase goods from the Haudenosaune. However, the true significance of wampum for the Haudenosaune lies in its gradual development from objects with religious significance into a method for maintaining permanent peace among distinct nations. Over time wampum came to be used to record and convey key sociopolitical messages. Wampum came in two colors, white and deep purple. Loose beads constituted the simplest and oldest form of wampum. Even in the form of loose beads, wampum could represent certain basic ideas. For example, white was associated with the sky-yearning spirit, Sapling, whose terrestrial creations, such as trees, were often beneficial to humanity; deep purple was associated with Sapling's twin brother, Flint, the earth-loving spirit whose frequent mischievous vandalism (e.g., in the form of storms) often severely disrupted human life. Legend indicates, for example, that ancient Haudenosaune anglers threw the beads into the water in which they fished to communicate with Sapling or Flint (differing versions of the Haudenosaune cosmology attribute the creation of fish to one or the other of these spirits). Later, loose beads were strung together forming string wampum. It is thought that string wampum was used to send simple political messages such as truce requests. It was, however, the formation of the Haudenosaune Confederacy from a group of warring tribes, believed by some to have occurred around 1451, that supplied the major impetus for making wampum a deliberate system of both arbitrary and pictorially derived symbols designed primarily for political purposes. This is evident in the invention of wampum belts to encode the provisions of the Haudenosaune Confederacy's constitution. These belts combined string wampum to form icons that could be deciphered by those knowing the significance of the stylized symbols. For example, longhouses, depicted in front-view outline, usually meant a particular nation of the confederacy. Council fires, possibly indicating talks in progress, were diamond outlines that could appear alone or within trees or longhouses. Lines between humanlike figures seem to have indicated the current state of relations between peoples; belts containing such images were often used as safe-conduct passes. The arrangements of the two colors also directed interpretation of the symbols. Thus, the belts served to record, store, and make publicly available items of governmental business. Although the wampum symbol system had a limited lexicon, it served to effectively frame and enforce the law of the confederacy for hundreds of years.
Question: The last paragraph of the passage serves primarily to
Choices:
  A: detail how wampum belts evolved from other forms of wampum
  B: distinguish between wampum belts and less complex forms of string wampum
  C: illustrate how wampum functioned as a system of symbolic representation
  D: outline the Haudenosaune Confederacy's constitution as it was encoded using wampum
  E: give evidence of wampum's effectiveness as a means of ensuring compliance with the law of the Haudenosaune Confederacy
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage is mainly about how the Haudenosaune used wampum.
  The passage explains that wampum was not just a form of money, but was also used for maintaining peace among nations and conveying key sociopolitical messages.
  Loose beads, string wampum, and wampum belts were different forms of wampum.
Thought: 
  The last paragraph of the passage mainly talks about wampum belts, which were designed primarily for political purposes.
  The paragraph explains how wampum belts evolved from other forms of wampum, how they functioned as a system of symbolic representation, and how they recorded and made publicly available items of governmental business.
  Therefore, the correct answer is C: illustrate how wampum functioned as a system of symbolic representation.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("C")

  The last paragraph of the passage describes the formation of the Haudenosaune Confederacy and the use of wampum belts to encode its constitution.
  A: The first sentence of the paragraph acknowledges that wampum had earlier forms.
  B: The paragraph mentions that string wampum was used to send simple political messages in the past. It does not distinguish between the belt and other forms of string wampum.
  C: The paragraph's primary focus is on how wampum, specifically wampum belts, functioned as a system of symbolic representation.
  D: While the paragraph mentions that wampum belts were used to encode the Haudenosaune Confederacy's constitution, it does not provide a detailed outline of its contents.
  E: The paragraph explains how wampum belts served to record, store, and publicly make available items of governmental business and maintained compliance with the law of the Haudenosaune Confederacy.

  It explains that the belts combined string wampum into icons and stylized symbols that could be deciphered by those who knew their significance.
  It further states that the belts served as records of governmental business and maintained compliance with the law of the confederacy.
  Therefore, the primary purpose of the paragraph is to illustrate how wampum functioned as a system of symbolic representation.
  The answer is C: illustrate how wampum functioned as a system of symbolic representation.
Criticism: 
  There seems to be no significant flaw in the thought process for this question. 
  All options except C are not supported by the information provided in the passage.
Action: Answer("C")

- Wampum served primarily as a political tool for maintaining peace among distinct nations and recording and conveying key sociopolitical messages.
- Wampum came in two colors, white and deep purple, and loose beads formed the simplest and oldest form.

  It talks about how the belts were used as a symbol system to encode the provisions of the Haudenosaune Confederacy's constitution.
  The paragraph highlights the various symbols used in wampum belts to represent political messages.
  It explains how the wampum belts effectively framed and enforced the law of the confederacy for hundreds of years.
  Thus, the primary purpose of the last paragraph is to illustrate how wampum functioned as a system of symbolic representation and provide evidence of wampum's effectiveness as a means of ensuring compliance with the law of the Haudenosaune Confederacy.
  Hence, the answer is C: illustrate how wampum functioned as a system of symbolic representation.
Criticism: None.
Action: Answer("C")

  Over time, wampum came to be used to record and convey key sociopolitical messages.
  Wampum belts were invented to encode the provisions of the Haudenosaune Confederacy's constitution, combining string wampum to form icons that could be deciphered by those knowing the significance of the stylized symbols.

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 90 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Passage A Insider-trading law makes it a crime to make stock transactions, or help others make stock transactions, based on information you have ahead of the general public because of your special position within a company. However, trading based on information you have that everyone else doesn't-isn't this part of the very definition of a functioning stock market? The entire field of stock brokering is based on people gaining knowledge that others don't have and then using it to profit themselves or their clients. If you analyze a stock, decide that it is overvalued, and sell it, you are taking advantage of knowledge that many others don?t have. That doesn't make you a criminal; it means you've done your homework. Stock markets work best when all the relevant information about a company is spread as widely as possible, as quickly as possible. Stock prices represent a constantly shifting amalgamation of everyone's information about and evaluations of a company's value. It helps when those who have accurate information about changing circumstances are permitted to act so that stock prices reflect them. Someone selling a stock because they know something will happen soon that will lower the stock's value helps spread the knowledge that the price ought to be dropping. Such actions help ensure that stock prices do reflect a more accurate assessment of all the relevant facts. That's good for everyone in the stock market. When contemplating insider-trading law, it helps to consider a far more widespread practice: "insider nontrading"-stock sales or purchases that would have been made, but aren't because of inside knowledge. This is certainly happening every day, and rightfully so. No one would think to lock someone up for it. Passage B One of the basic principles of the stock market is transparency. In a transparent market, information that influences trading decisions is available to all participants at the same time. Success in the market can then be gained only by skill in analyzing the information and making good investing decisions. In a transparent stock market-everyone has the same chance of making a good investment, and success is based on individual merit and skill. In insider-trading situations, some people make investment decisions based on information that other people don't have. People who don't have access to the inside information can make similarly informed investment decisions. That unfairly compromises the market: people with inside information can make informed trade decisions far before everyone else, making it difficult or impossible for other people to earn money in the stock market. This, in turn, causes a loss of investor confidence and could ultimately destroy the market. People invest in the stock market because they believe they can make money. The whole point of capital investments is to make good investing decisions and make money over time. If investors believe they can't make money, they won't invest. Undermining investor confidence would thus deny companies access to the funds they need to grow and be successful, and it could ultimately lead to widespread financial repercussions.
Question: Which one of the following laws would conform most closely to the position articulated by the author of passage A but not that articulated by the author of passage B?
Choices:
  A: a law that prohibits trading based on information that is not shared by everyone
  B: a law that permits trading based on information gained from analysis of a stock but prohibits trading based on information obtained from one's position within a company
  C: a law that prohibits trading that could reasonably be expected to undermine investors' confidence in the stock market
  D: a law that legalizes selling based on inside information that a stock's price ought to be dropping but prohibits buying based on inside information that it should be rising
  E: a law that legalizes trading based on inside information, as long as that information is not acquired by theft or other unlawful means
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Passage A suggests that stock markets work best when all the relevant information about a company is spread as widely as possible, as quickly as possible, and that the use of information that everyone else doesn't have is not necessarily a crime.
  Passage B argues that insider-trading situations compromise the transparency of the market and therefore undermine investor confidence, which could ultimately destroy the market.
Thought:
  Both passages discuss the principles of transparency and fairness in the stock market, but they have different positions on insider trading.
  Passage A suggests that insider trading is not necessarily a crime and that it can be beneficial to the stock market as long as the information is spread widely.
  Passage B argues that insider trading compromises the market's transparency and undermines investor confidence, which could lead to financial repercussions.
  Therefore, the law that conforms most closely to the position articulated by the author of passage A but not by the author of passage B would permit trading based on information gained from analysis of a stock but prohibits trading based on information obtained from one's position within a company.
  The answer is B: a law that permits trading based on information gained from analysis of a stock but prohibits trading based on information obtained from one's position within a company.
Criticism:
  None
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Passage A argues that stock markets work best when all relevant information about a company is spread quickly and widely and when people are permitted to act upon that information. It implies that insider trading can contribute to improving the accuracy of stock prices, although it carefully avoids outright endorsement of insider trading. Passage B, on the other hand, emphasizes the importance of transparency and fairness in the stock market and implies that insider trading undermines both. To find the law that conforms most closely to the position articulated by the author of Passage A but not that of Passage B, we need to look for a law that allows trading based on information that is not shared by everyone but also places restrictions on insider trading when such trading harms the integrity of the stock market. Choice B comes closest to this position by restricting insider trading in a company's stock based on information that is not open to everyone, while allowing trading based on analysis of the company's stock. However, choice B is not a perfect match as it does not take into account the possibility that insider trading can undermine investor confidence in the market. Therefore, we can eliminate all other choices except choice B, which is the best answer.

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 91 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Neurobiologists once believed that the workings of the brain were guided exclusively by electrical signals; according to this theory, communication between neurons (brain cells) is possible because electrical impulses travel from one neuron to the next by literally leaping across the synapses (gaps between neurons). But many neurobiologists puzzled over how this leaping across synapses might be achieved, and as early as 1904 some speculated that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically rather than electrically. According to this alternative theory, the excited neuron secretes a chemical called a neurotransmitter that binds with its corresponding receptor molecule in the receiving neuron. This binding of the neurotransmitter renders the neuron permeable to ions, and as the ions move into the receiving neuron they generate an electrical impulse that runs through the cell; the electrical impulse is thereby transmitted to the receiving neuron. This theory has gradually won acceptance in the scientific community, but for a long time little was known about the mechanism by which neurotransmitters manage to render the receiving neuron permeable to ions. In fact, some scientists remained skeptical of the theory because they had trouble imagining how the binding of a chemical to a receptor at the cell surface could influence the flow of ions through the cell membrane. Recently, however, researchers have gathered enough evidence for a convincing explanation: that the structure of receptors plays the pivotal role in mediating the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity. The new evidence shows that receptors for neurotransmitters contain both a neurotransmitter binding site and a separate region that functions as a channel for ions; attachment of the neurotransmitter to the binding site causes the receptor to change shape and so results in the opening of its channel component. Several types of receptors have been isolated that conform to this structure, among them the receptors for acetylcholine, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), glycine, and serotonin. These receptors display enough similarities to constitute a family, known collectively as neurotransmitter-gated ion channels. It has also been discovered that each of the receptors in this family comes in several varieties so that, for example, a GABA receptor in one part of the brain has slightly different properties than a GABA receptor in another part of the brain. This discovery is medically significant because it raises the possibility of the highly selective treatment of certain brain disorders. As the precise effect on behavior of every variety of each neurotransmitter-gated ion channel is deciphered, pharmacologists may be able to design drugs targeted to specific receptors on defined categories of neurons that will selectively impede or enhance these effects. Such drugs could potentially help ameliorate any number of debilitating conditions, including mood disorders, tissue damage associated with stroke, or Alzheimer's disease.
Question: Which one of the following most completely and accurately states the main point of the passage?
Choices:
  A: Evidence shows that the workings of the brain are guided, not by electrical signals, but by chemicals, and that subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals may permit the selective treatment of certain brain disorders.
  B: Evidence shows that the workings of the brain are guided, not by electrical signals, but by chemicals, and that enough similarities exist among these chemicals to allow scientists to classify them as a family.
  C: Evidence shows that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically rather than electrically, and that enough similarities exist among these chemicals to allow scientists to classify them as a family.
  D: Evidence shows that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically rather than electrically, and that subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals may permit the selective treatment of certain brain disorders.
  E: Evidence shows that receptor molecules in the brain differ subtly from one another, and that these differences can be exploited to treat certain brain disorders through the use of drugs that selectively affect particular parts of the brain.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses an alternative theory to the idea that the brain is guided exclusively by electrical signals.
  According to this theory, communication between neurons is possible because of chemical signals transmitted across synapses.
  The excited neuron secretes a neurotransmitter that binds with its corresponding receptor molecule in the receiving neuron.
  This binding renders the neuron permeable to ions, which generates an electrical impulse that runs through the cell and is thereby transmitted to the receiving neuron.
  The structure of receptors plays a pivotal role in mediating the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity.
  Neurotransmitter-gated ion channels have been identified, and receptors within this family come in several varieties with slightly different properties that may permit the selective treatment of certain brain disorders.
Thought: 
  The passage discusses an alternative theory to the idea that the brain is guided exclusively by electrical signals. 
  This alternative theory involves chemical signals transmitted across synapses and involves the secretion of neurotransmitters that bind with its corresponding receptor molecule in the receiving neuron. 
  The structure of these receptors plays a pivotal role in mediating the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity. 
  The passage also discusses how neurotransmitter-gated ion channels have been identified and the receptors within this family come in several varieties with slightly different properties that may permit the selective treatment of certain brain disorders. 
  Therefore, the main point of the passage is that chemical signals, transmitted through receptor molecules that vary slightly from one another, play a key role in the way the brain works and could be used to design drugs that selectively affect particular parts of the brain to help treat various brain disorders.
  Answer (E) is the most completely and accurately states the main point of the passage.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses the workings of the brain and how neurons communicate with each other through neurotransmitters and receptors. 
  One of the theories on communication between neurons is that electrical impulses travel from one neuron to the next by literally leaping across synapses (gaps between neurons).
  An alternative theory proposes that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically rather than electrically through the secretion and binding of a chemical called a neurotransmitter that binds with its corresponding receptor molecule in the receiving neuron.
  Receptors for neurotransmitters contain both a neurotransmitter binding site and a separate region that functions as a channel for ions. The attachment of the neurotransmitter to the binding site causes the receptor to change shape and open its channel component which results in the transmission of electrical impulses to the receiving neuron. 
  Enough similarities exist among these neurotransmitters that allow scientists to classify them as a family, and each receptor in this family also has several varieties. 
Thought: 
  The main point of this passage is that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically through the secretion and binding of a chemical called a neurotransmitter that binds with its corresponding receptor molecule in the receiving neuron. The structure of receptors plays a pivotal role in mediating the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity since they contain both a neurotransmitter binding site and a separate region that functions as a channel for ions. Enough similarities exist among these neurotransmitters that allow scientists to classify them as a family, and each receptor in this family also has several varieties. This discovery is medically significant because it raises the possibility of the highly selective treatment of certain brain disorders. 
  The answer is D: Evidence shows that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically rather than electrically, and that subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals may permit the selective treatment of certain brain disorders. 
Criticism: 
  None
Action: Answer("D")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses two theories of how neurons communicate: via electrical impulses and via neurotransmitters.
  The initial theory was that neurons communicated via electrical impulses.
  The alternative theory proposed that neurotransmitters bind with their corresponding receptors in the receiving neuron, rendering the neuron permeable to ions, and generating an electrical impulse that runs through the cell.
  Research has found evidence for the alternative theory, which suggests that neurotransmitters are key to the workings of the brain.
  The chemical structure of receptors that bind with neurotransmitters and the opening of its channel component play a pivotal role in mediating the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity.
Thought:
  The passage discusses two theories of how neurons communicate and the evidence for the alternative theory.
  Evidence shows that the workings of the brain are guided, not by electrical signals, but by chemicals and that the structure of receptors that bind with neurotransmitters plays a pivotal role in mediating the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity.
  The subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals could make possible the selective treatment of certain brain disorders.
  Therefore, the main point of this passage is that the neurotransmitter theory is the best explanation of how neurons communicate, and it could lead to the development of drugs to treat specific brain disorders based on the subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals.
  The answer is D: Evidence shows that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically rather than electrically, and that subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals may permit the selective treatment of certain brain disorders. 
Criticism: None.
Response 3:
Knowledge:
Neurobiologists once believed that the workings of the brain were guided only by electrical signals, but there was no solid theory on how the impulses could leap across synapses. Then, in 1904, some neurobiologists speculated that electrical impulses are generated chemically. Neurobiologists believed that the neurotransmitters secreted by the excited neuron make the receiving neuron permeable to ions, allowing ions to move from one neuron to another neuron, and thereby generating an electrical impulse in the receiving neuron.
Thought:
The main point of the passage revolves around how the mechanism of transferring electrical impulses between neurons has changed from electrical to chemical signals through neurotransmitters. It mainly talks about how these neurotransmitters affect different parts of ion channels and the potential use of highly selective drugs to target specific areas of the brain to enhance or impede the effects of different neurotransmitters. Therefore, the correct answer should mention the chemical mechanism, neurotransmitter receptors and their varying effects on behaviors in different parts of the brain, and their implications for potential future treatments. 
A, B, and C only partially mention relevant details present in the passage. 
Option E includes receptor differences and treatment of brain disorders, but it does not mention anything about the chemical mechanism of neurotransmitter signaling. 
Therefore, the most correct option is D: Evidence shows that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically rather than electrically, and that subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals may permit the selective treatment of certain brain disorders. 
Criticism:
The option could have been even more accurate if it included a mention of neurotransmitter-gated ion channels. While Option D mentions subtle differences among the receptors for these chemicals that allow the selective treatment of certain brain disorders, it does not explicitly mention neurotransmitter-gated ion channels, which are a fundamental aspect of this mechanism. 
Action: Answer("D")
Response 4:
Knowledge:
  The passage discusses the two contrasting theories of neural communication, electrical and chemical.
  The alternative theory of chemical signaling is by the secretion of neurotransmitters, which bind to receptor molecules on the receiving neuron's surface and open its channel component, generating an electrical impulse.
  Receptors for neurotransmitters contain a neurotransmitter binding site and a separate region that functions as a channel for ions.
  These receptors, known as neurotransmitter-gated ion channels, come in different varieties, and researchers can design drugs targeted to specific receptors to selectively treat certain brain disorders.
Thought:
  The main point of the passage is about:
  - the mechanism of neural communication, which is achieved by chemical signals instead of electrical signals;
  - the discovery of receptors to mediate the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity;
  - the possibility of selective treatment of certain brain disorders by designing drugs targeted to specific receptors.
  Option A correctly summarizes all three main ideas of the passage.

Response 5:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses two theories about how communication between neurons in the brain is possible. The first theory posits that the workings of the brain are guided exclusively by electrical signals, while the second theory suggests that they are guided by chemicals, specifically, neurotransmitters.
  The neurotransmitter theory posits that an excited neuron secretes a chemical neurotransmitter that binds with a corresponding receptor molecule in the receiving neuron. This binding then renders the neuron permeable to ions, allowing an electrical impulse to be transmitted to the receiving neuron.
  Recent evidence shows that receptors for neurotransmitters contain both a neurotransmitter binding site and a separate region that functions as a channel for ions.
  The discovery that each receptor in the family of neurotransmitter-gated ion channels comes in several varieties suggests the highly selective treatment of certain brain disorders through drugs targeted to specific receptors on defined categories of neurons.

Response 6:

  One theory suggests that electrical impulses travel from one neuron to the next by literally leaping across the synapses, while the other theory suggests that electrical impulses are transmitted between neurons chemically.
  The second theory, which is about the transmission of electrical impulses between neurons chemically, is gradually winning acceptance in the scientific community.
  The mechanism by which neurotransmitters manage to render the receiving neuron permeable to ions was once unknown, but it is now known that the structure of receptors plays the pivotal role in mediating the conversion of chemical signals into electrical activity.
  The receptors for neurotransmitters contain both a neurotransmitter binding site and a separate region that functions as a channel for ions; attachment of the neurotransmitter to the binding site causes the receptor to change shape and so results in the opening of its channel component.
  Each of the receptors in neurotransmitter-gated ion channels comes in several varieties so that pharmacologists may be able to design drugs targeted to specific receptors on defined categories of neurons that will selectively increase or decrease certain effects.

### Model: gpt-35-turbo | Prompt: composite | Exam: lsat-rc-100 | Problem 92 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: An organism is considered to have an infection when a disease-causing agent, called a pathogen, establishes a viable presence in the organism. This can occur only if the pathogenic agent is able to reproduce itself in the host organism. The only agents believed until recently to be responsible for infections—viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites—reproduce and regulate their other life processes by means of genetic material, composed of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA). It was thus widely assumed that all pathogens contain such genetic material in their cellular structure. This assumption has been challenged, however, by scientists seeking to identify the pathogen that causes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a degenerative form of dementia in humans. CJD causes the brain to become riddled with tiny holes, like a sponge (evidence of extensive nerve cell death). Its symptoms include impaired muscle control, loss of mental acuity, memory loss, and chronic insomnia. Extensive experiments aimed at identifying the pathogen responsible for CJD have led surprisingly to the isolation of a disease agent lacking nucleic acid and consisting mainly, if not exclusively, of protein. Researchers coined the term "prion" for this new type of protein pathogen. Upon further study, scientists discovered that prions normally exist as harmless cellular proteins in many of the body's tissues, including white blood cells and nerve cells in the brain; however, they possess the capability of converting their structures into a dangerous abnormal shape. Prions exhibiting this abnormal conformation were found to have infectious properties and the ability to reproduce themselves in an unexpected way, by initiating a chain reaction that induces normally shaped prions to transform themselves on contact, one after another, into the abnormal, pathogenic conformation. This cascade of transformations produces a plaque, consisting of thread-like structures, that collects in the brain and ultimately destroys nerve cells. Because prions, unlike other pathogens, occur naturally in the body as proteins, the body does not produce an immune response when they are present. And in the absence of any effective therapy for preventing the cascade process by which affected prions reproduce themselves, CJD is inevitably fatal, though there are wide variations in pre-symptomatic incubation times and in how aggressively the disease progresses. Although the discovery of the link between prions and CJD was initially received with great skepticism in the scientific community, subsequent research has supported the conclusion that prions are an entirely new class of infectious pathogens. Furthermore, it is now believed that a similar process of protein malformation may be involved in other, more common degenerative neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. This possibility has yet to be fully explored, however, and the exact mechanisms by which prions reproduce themselves and cause cellular destruction have yet to be completely understood.
Question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the passage?
Choices:
  A: The only way in which CJD can be transmitted is through the injection of abnormally shaped prions from an infected individual into an uninfected individual.
  B: Most infectious diseases previously thought to be caused by other pathogens are now thought to be caused by prions.
  C: If they were unable to reproduce themselves, abnormally shaped prions would not cause CJD.
  D: Alzheimers disease and Parkinson's disease are caused by different conformations of the same prion pathogen that causes CJD.
  E: Prion diseases generally progress more aggressively than diseases caused by other known pathogens.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a degenerative disease caused by a new type of pathogen called prions, which is composed mainly of protein.
  Prions can reproduce themselves and cause cellular destruction through a chain reaction by initiating a transformation of normally shaped prions into an abnormal, pathogenic conformation.
Thought:
  Abnormally shaped prions, which are composed mainly of protein and lack nucleic acid, are capable of reproducing themselves and cause CJD by initiating a chain reaction by transforming normally shaped prions into an abnormal conformation.
  If they were unable to reproduce themselves, abnormally shaped prions would not cause CJD.
  Alzheimers disease and Parkinson's disease may be caused differently from CJD, but they may involve a similar process of protein malformation.
  There is no support for the claim that CJD can only be transmitted through injection or that most infectious diseases result from prions.
  There is no evidence in the passage to suggest that prion diseases progress more aggressively than other diseases.
  Therefore, choice C is most strongly supported by the passage.
Action: Answer("C")

  Prions are naturally occurring proteins in the body that can convert their structures into a dangerous abnormal shape, which can reproduce by inducing normally shaped prions to transform themselves on contact into the abnormal pathogenic conformation; this cascade transformation process ultimately destroys nerve cells.
